document.masterDocTitle: Two new species of the genus Sinotilla Lelej, 1995 (Hymenoptera: Mutillidae), with notes on taxonomic characters

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Two new species of the genus Sinotilla Lelej, 1995 (Hymenoptera: Mutillidae), with notes on taxonomic characters

bibRefCitation.author: Lelej, A. S.
bibRefCitation.refString: Lelej, A. S. (1995 a) A review of Palaearctic and Oriental species of genus Nemka Lelej with description of Oriental genus Mickelomyrme gen. n. (Hymenoptera, Mutillidae). Far Eastern Entomologist, 6, 1 - 20.
bibRefCitation.title: A review of Palaearctic and Oriental species of genus Nemka Lelej with description of Oriental genus Mickelomyrme gen. n. (Hymenoptera, Mutillidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Sinotilla Lelej, 1995b : 18
. Type species:
Smicromyrme boheana Chen, 1957
, ♂, by original designation.

Diagnosis. FEMALE. Hypostomal teeth present ( Fig. 30 ). Clypeus with protruding transverse lamellate carina on anterior margin and with median basal tubercle. Mandible slender. Fore tarsi without external comb of spines. Scutellar scale weak but distinct. T2 with apical narrow band of dense, appressed setae, slightly widened medially; T3 with wide uniform band of dense, appressed setae ( Figs 8 , 16 , 24 ). T6 lacking distinct flattened pygidium, glabrous, unsculptured, polished and remarkably convergent basally with lateral margins not carinated even apically ( Figs 6 , 14 , 22 ). Diagnosis for male is given by Lelej (1995b) and not repeated here.
Distribution. Eastern Palaearctic and Oriental regions.

Biology.
Sinotilla decora
emerged from nests of a widely distributed, mud-daubing solitary wasp
Pison argentatum Shuckard
( Hymenoptera : Crabronidae ) ( Pagden 1934 ), which is also known as a hunter of both webbuilding and non-web-building spiders of Salticidae , Araneidae , Lycosidae and
Oxyopidae ( Starr 2004 )
. Pagden (1934) mentioned that this species probably attacks other species of
Pison
as well.

Remarks. Among the genera of Smicromyrmini, females of this genus are similar to those of
Ephucilla Lelej, 1995
and Indratilla
Lelej, 1993 in
having weak but distinct scutellar scale and unsculptured pygidial area. It can be separated by lacking lateral carina on pygidial area which remarkably convergent basally (in
Ephucilla
and Indratilla pygidial area elongated and weakly carinated laterally).

Discussion. The females of
Sinotilla
species can be divided into four expedient groups by the following character states of T2: 1) T2 with a basal median spot of setae and bluish metallic luster (
decora
and
contractula
); 2) T2 with a basal median spot and black integument (
belokobylskiji
,
lambirensis
and
petina
); 3) T2 without basal median spot and uniformly black (
subparallela
and
yakushimensis
); 4) T2 without basal median spot but with bluish metallic luster (
cyaneiventris
and
pekiniana
). Below, two new species belonging to group 2 are described.
